job_title: Program Coordinator, Undergraduate Medical Education in Gainesville, FL
pros: Health insurance is definitely why I chose this job. Access to UFs affordable plans gives you several options for insurance carriers and plan levels, with free stuff offered at no cost to the employee. Vacation time is pretty good, almost standard across the board, unless you are an essential employee. But with holiday closures and vacay/ sick approval, it's comfortable. Safe work environment physically, with very close access to hospitals. (not emotionally safe?)
cons: Parking is expensive and a nightmare. I would guess it's comparable to other college campuses, and cities where you would have to pay to park. But ticketing and towing are excessive and punitive, not to mention not entirely ADA compliant. Depending on your college and department, the workplace can be very toxic emotionally. Wage discrepancies are abundant, and many policies are arbitrarily enforced. Depending on your career trajectory, there may be few career development options or tenure and promotion tracks for staff—only faculty. (MyTraining is only beneficial for UF career paths - useless outside of the University)

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: None I can think of.
cons: This school is highway robbery. Even Graduate Teaching Assistants who WORK for the university have to pay. The worst medical insurance in the country, even for full-time faculty. Their medical insurance does not pay for birth control pills, even if the pills are taken for medical reason. They will try to cheat you out of your money at every opportunity. Every time they want to deny you one of your rights (deduction from your paycheck for insurance, for instance), re-read your contract. They are expert at violating their own contract. You must assume that this university will not respect their own contract. You must question everything, it gets very tiring at the end. If you threaten them through the union, they will back down. They are UNWILLING to spread your paycheck over 12 months. You must save your money during the academic year in order not to starve during the summer. Why? Nobody can explain. For the schedule of classes, they use the stupid "period system", that nobody has memorized. Only 2 weeks for winter break. WTF? If you teach online, you have to do it from your classroom (not from home), just in case some students want to attend a face-to-face class! Then, you have the terrible smell, but it is all over the city, not just the campus.

review_title: Good Job for Building up Work Experience
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: I most value how much I learned and experienced through this role. I enjoyed that this job allowed me to work with a range of students my age (from undergrads to PhD's) as well as with long-time professionals in the field. I think this exposed me to different teaching styles and perspectives that rounded out my experience. I appreciated how much my boss encouraged questions and invested time into teaching me the skills I needed to succeed. I think this position offered a great jumping block to develop more skills for work after graduation.
cons:
I felt like limited respect for gender diversity was one con of this position. Unfortunately, I feel like women were looked down upon and occasionally treated poorly by a few lab members. 
Another con was poor work, school, and life balance. Students having some trouble balancing all of the above is understandable. But I feel like this lab in particular was understaffed, putting an inordinate amount of work on some members of my team.

review_title: Are you a high achiever or a mediocre person?
pros: One of the biggest playgrounds for a creative mind to work - a top-5 public university with unique levels of excellence and endless stories to tell. Great benefits.
cons:
Nothing describes higher ed employment better than this quote from Nick Saban: "Mediocre people don't like high achievers, and high achievers don't like mediocre people." 

Many, many mediocre professionals get very cutthroat at higher levels at places like UF to preserve the cruise control status quo journey they are on. If you need stability and state benefits, it's a great place to put your head down and work. If you are an ambitious boundary-pusher always seeking to improve and do more/better for the sake of something bigger than yourself, be prepared to step on many toes along the way. Caring for the institution means less to them than it does to you. They usually have little interest in change, and will be threatened by your insistence that change is positive -- no matter how tactful or friendly you are, or how much expertise you bring to the conversation. For staff positions especially, if you enjoy navigating territorialism and Peter Principle politics, a job in higher ed might be for you.

I worked with some truly spectacular minds in my 9+ years there, and I also worked with some of the highest paid borderline incompetents I've ever labored under.  Coming from the private sector, I wasn't cut out for the long haul in higher ed.

Remote work options are EXTREMELY limited. Decisions are made based on politics, with no thought of consulting the people with technical expertise. There is no forward thinking or proactive strategy, everything is a kneejerk reaction. I could go on and on, but I'll sum it up like this.... everyday is like working in the circus as a clown, and the big top is on fire, and you're riding in a clown car that's on fire, spinning out of control, with the stereo blasting circus music at full volume. Please consider applying elsewhere.

pros: Great place for teaching experience. Assistantships are worth it when the professor hires you ahead of deadlines in order to secure appropriate compensation - otherwise, get ready to work more than you're getting reasonably paid. It's a sign of a good boss if the planning is finished well before the end of the previous semester; otherwise, get ready for an unorganized semester. Most of the time, there was organization and planning in place. The teaching experience is amazing if you find a professor that offers labs, teaching of some lectures, etc. Know what you want to get out of being an assistant, and THERE ARE OPTIONS FOR YOU. The possibilities at UF are endless. Pay depends on the job and college. That said, there are amazing TA positions available - just do your research first on what's available and what your boss will be like to work with. Don't take the first offer; find the best. If you find the best for you, there is certainly no better place to be. :)
cons: While some professors will be amazing teaching mentors, not all professors treat their assistants well. Some professors will only use their assistants as proctors, secretary-level graders, and to handle online grading because they don't know how to use digital gradebooks, which is frankly a waste of time if you're a graduate student looking for teaching experience and that is all you are allowed to do. The subject of the course also determines this, so bear in mind what you are trying to get teaching experience in. Make sure you understand what your duties are going to be before you sign a whole semester or more away to a position that won't help your portfolio.

pros:
- An actual minimum wage job that accurately expects minimum, but acceptable, work.
- Coworkers are fun to meet and chat with. You might actually make friends in this role.
- The desk clerks give good life advice. They're pleasant enough for people only making $30k +/- some thousands a year.
- The work schedule system is awesome. 
- Minimal training is needed to succeed in the role.
- Residents are rarely mean.
- You have access to some UF employee perks.
cons:
- No benefits package. They actively make sure you do not reach full-time hours.
- No room to grow or even hope of becoming a desk clerk unlike other minimum wage jobs where you can work to become a team lead or shift supervisor.
- I worked at multiple desks, and each desk clerk was picky about certain things. It can be a lot to remember how to not anger every desk clerk, and they WOULD get visibly annoyed if I forgot that they liked something to be a particular way.
- One of the desk clerks seemed prejudice, or if not prejudice, they somehow only ever hired non-POC people as anchor desk assistants.
- Work is tied to the status of UF, so be prepared to be unemployed for however long UF is down.

review_title: Run, Don’t Walk Away | Biotility at UF
pros:
Work/life balance - overtime rarely required, easy to get time off. 

No micro management - you’re free to run the programs you want, but that really creates a con for people who are not motivated.
cons:
Culture - no team-building events, cliquey. 

No onboarding program - on my first day, there was 1 person in the office who showed me to my desk and that was the extent of any onboarding. You’re really thrown into the fire here.

No organization - meetings and external events constantly cancelled/moved because people “forgot”. Nobody plans for even 3 months out.

No growth - we’re dealing with a public institution here which means that promotions and raises happen at an extremely slow pace.

No change - traditional and old ideals, people are afraid to create campaigns that reflect current trends.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros:
At the University of Florida I found free to do research supported by state of the art facilities and very helpful staff. I learn from the best professors and had a vibrant work environment. While working at the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, I had opportunity to interface with researchers from other departments (e.g., Industrial and Systems Engineering and Statistics), universities (e.g., Penn State University, University of Michigan, and Virginia Tech) and also from industry (e.g., Boeing and NASA). Altogether, it as valuable experience for networking.

The University of Florida is a multicultural place. People come from all over the world and they feel welcome. For example, I worked in a lab that had French, Indian, Korean, Chinese, Israeli, Turkish, and Brazilian students. Besides all that I got technically speaking, the exposure to such rich diversity contributed to my understanding of different cultures and people.

The University of Florida has the main campus in Gainesville, which is also an extremely pleasant place to live. Despite the fact that it is a college town, it offers culture, churches, dinning, sports, and shopping. It is very safe and family friendly. On top of that, Gainesville is only two hours from beaches, theme parks and international airports.
cons: Some of the downsides of working at the University of Florida is that once you graduate there is not a whole lot for you. Gainesville is a college town, meaning that you better do not fall in love for the city because chances are that if you are not academically oriented you might have to move.

pros: The graduate school lifestyle is very flexible and allows you to have a lot of freedom over how you spend your time. The progress you make is dependent on you alone. cons: Lack of recognition and structure for graduate students, many of the requirements for graduation are ambiguous and leads to unfair treatment. Some students can graduate with less achievements than others. There needs to be a system in place to keep students on track because the years can pass by pretty quickly if you're not driven and goal oriented. Another drawback is that students in the college of letters and sciences have to worry about budget cuts and how it may affect them. Sometimes the reputation as a party school can make you feel less respected based on how the rest of society perceives us.

review_title: After doing my Ph.D. and 2 years of Postdoc, UF is not an impressive prospect when compared across the field
pros:
UF has some phenomenal facilities for research and at least says its trying to build itself into a top 10 research facility.
The new research facilities are gorgeous and well appointed.
Individual groups within the university and departments can be incredibly strong (i.e. the diabetes group in the Dept. of Pathology, or the virology group in Molecular Genetics and Microbiology)
cons:
Postdoctoral career development is hilariously absent.  As is common in academia, any and all real career development is entirely dependent on your individual PI, so the experience is highly variable from lab to lab.
My benefits as a post-doc are less comprehensive than my partner's, who is a laboratory technician (she accrues PTO at twice the rate I do, and her insurance is much better).
Any attempts to regulate the work-life balance of postdocs is lip service as there is no standardized time accountability for postdocs, though this is common in the field.
As is also common at large universities, the overwhelming cultural focus on the football team as priority number one is frustrating.  Need to get to the lab on the weekend?  Too bad, as campus is nearly inaccessible.
There is no employee parking anywhere near the health science center.

pros: Flexible hours, good work-life balance, good benefits including health insurance and a 5.14 percent match retirement plan. Pay is above average (but not high) for creative positions.
cons:
University bureaucracy can lead to weeks of feeling unproductive. Many projects, articles, social media campaigns or ideas die before launch because of lack of action or approval from higher-ups.

Human resources staff is sub-par if anything goes wrong with benefits, which has happened to me several times.

Poor employees are kept on, while no effort is made to retain high-performing employees, many of whom bounce from department to department yearly to secure incremental raises.

Top-level administration is exceptionally poor (not at a department level, but at the top-brass level) - especially when it comes to developing employees or creating position codes to help workers gain incremental increases in responsibility and pay as they mature in their roles. Position codes must be adhered to when hiring and they are written from a mid-1990s perspective with no thought toward current high-demand skills. Many highly skilled individuals are only half-utilized due to this, and leave positions due to feeling unfulfilled.

review_title: An excellent university to develop your career
job_title: Post Doctoral Research Scientist in Gainesville, FL
pros: The University of Florida has a great community, and the city of Gainesville has a lot to offer cultural and sporting activities despite its size. Living costs are lower than other regions of the US, and the quality of research is very high in many departments. The city is very welcoming to foreign nationals. The university offers a lot of career development opportunities and events. Hiring practices differ across the departments of the university, but are generally transparent. There are many opportunities for collaborative research if one is interested in pursuing it. In interested in transitioning to non-academic posts, there are free services offered to the community on training, CV and interview preparation, and networking with industries, as well as specific workshop opportunities.
cons: Post docs are lost a bit in the hierarchy of the University, but the personnel at the office of post doctoral affairs was helpful with my necessities and has been working on ways to improve situation for post docs campus-wide. The international visitors office was receptive but sometimes unclear on how to help with some issues. Overall, paper work is slow to work through the University's system, in many ways. The particular HR representative at my department was more a hindrance than help, and would sometimes give incomplete information or instructions. Post doc salaries tend to be equal or slightly above national average, but specific employment opportunities may differ.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Gainesville, FL
pros: Not a lot of oversight, so you have freedom when it comes to designing the curriculum for your own courses, which makes it way more fun and productive for you and way more fun and productive for your students. Generally you have the opportunity to teach a variety of different courses, and the administration will try to work with your preferences.
cons: INSANE bureaucracy, but that comes with working for such a large university I suppose. Low pay. It's enough to live on in Gainesville, which is a super cheap, fun town (just don't live anywhere near campus) but it's not enough if you're worrying about student loans or literally anything other than rent, bills, food, and drinking your troubles away. Fees are getting higher and higher, and go towards things that contribute to undergraduate life, not your life, which is super frustrating. Health insurance is decent, but they'll inevitably screw up your coverage at the beginning of every new cycle so beware if there are prescriptions you rely on. UF is letting fantastic professors get nabbed by other universities, and at least within the humanities it seems like adjunct professors are doing the work that tenured professors should be doing, and PhD/MA teaching assistants are just really insanely underpaid adjunct professors.

review_title: Where academic careers go to die
pros: Excellent climate, beautiful central campus, attracted some top-notch talent, many of whom remain
cons:
UF is  a particularly egregious instance of academic mismanagement, which morphed from being a can-do place, run by talented and enlightened administrators to an environment where incompetence is an asset. Administrators pressure faculty to push students into badly run graduate programs with ramshackle curricula and zero job prospects, post-graduation. My particular college had a roster of former program directors who appointed spouses (and other family members) to administrative and faculty positions, where they performed so poorly that the college rotated them into non-teaching or non-administrative positions, all while paying them salaries in the $200K+ range for jobs where they neither taught courses nor performed any duties.

Being a faculty member here was like being aboard the Titanic after the last lifeboat departed. Eventually, you jump ship and take your chances that the university will bad-mouth you for leaving or even lie about you remaining here, as it did with four of my former colleagues who had left years earlier but were still on the faculty roster of their departments (a fact that surprised all of them). Or you let the ship suck you down with it.
